urls.title: Ke Huy Quan’s True Hollywood Comeback
urls.description: ‘Indiana Jones’ and ‘The Goonies’ made him a child star in the ’80s. Then Hollywood forgot about him. Nearly 40 years later, Quan opens up about ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ and the part that took a lifetime to find.

data.text: @VanityFair @A24 https://t.co/4klSDG6cgy

“I was famished for a role like this. When I stepped in front of the camera, I felt alive. I don't know how to explain it, but it was a feeling that I haven't had for decades. ” Ke Huy Quan on stepping in front of the camera again 💫 #EverythingEverywhere @VanityFair https://t.co/INVl2UjnNX

urls.title: Daniels Domination: How the Farting Corpse Guys Became Oscar Contenders
urls.description: Directing duo Daniels (Kwan and Scheinert) have come a long way since Daniel Radcliffe's flatulent reanimated corpse prompted walkouts at the 2016 Sundance premiere of ‘Swiss Army Man.' THR’s Young Filmmakers of the Year talk obsessively planning for worst-case scenarios, their 13-year partnership, and what to expect after buzzy 'Everything Everywhere All at Once.'

urls.title: With a comeback like no other, Ke Huy Quan can again embrace his dream of acting
urls.description: He was a young favorite -- Short Round in 'Temple of Doom,' Data in 'The Goonies' -- then he left acting, or rather, acting left him. Now he's back in 'Everything Everywhere All at Once.'

data.text:
“It took courage to give voice to this dream I’d had, a dream I had to walk away from, and I didn’t think it would find its way back.” – Ke Huy Quan on his remarkable (& remarkably well-deserved) big screen comeback with #EverythingEverywhere ⭐️

https://t.co/6HEIkri4D3

urls.title: At 93, Actor James Hong Reflects on Breaking Barriers and Seminal Roles
urls.description: The 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' legend and Critics Choice Icon Award recipient looks back on his over 700 roles and how Asian representation has changed: "When I was a kid, [1937’s] 'The Good Earth' was played by Caucasian leads that taped their eyes up."

urls.title: 'It's fate.' 40 years later, Ke Huy Quan is a star, again
urls.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Ke Huy Quan is trying hard not to cry. He's been crying a lot lately. Quan tends to get emotional any time he contemplates his sudden reversal of fate. Every since “Everything Everywhere All at Once” opened in theaters earlier this year, 51-year-old Quan — who a lifetime ago was the iconic child star of “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,” as Short Round, and Data in “Goonies" — has been, he says, “overwhelmed by emotions every day.”

tweets.text:
Ke Huy Quan was once one of the most indelible faces — and voices — of the 1980s. But by the time Quan was in his 20s, he had all but disappeared from the screen.

Now, he’s being celebrated for one of the best performances of the year. https://t.co/PsJfAU7W8a

urls.title: The Images of 'Everything Everywhere All at Once': Absurdity, Authenticity, and a Lot of Improvisation
urls.description: “I’m the janitor, if you will,” says cinematographer Larkin Seiple of working with the Daniels. “I’m constantly trying to clean things up that are crazy, and make them feel ordinary.”

tweets.text:

My favorite things of 2022: Everything Everywhere All At Once

Probably my movie of the year–and what a special movie it was. It somehow was able to insert meaningful and emotional moments of brevity into an otherwise wacky narrative. https://t.co/MhPVc0gAVg

Finally watching Everything Everywhere All At Once and it's...wonderful.

Stop what you're doing and immediately watch: 'Everything Everywhere All At Once'. A brilliant, funny, quirky, trippy, rollicking ride of a movie. About a Chinese laundrette owner who is just trying to do her taxes...and other stuff..  in multiple universes.

“When I choose to see the good side of things, I'm not being naive. It is strategic and necessary. It's how I've learned to survive through everything.”

— Waymond Wang (Ke Huy Quan), “Everything, Everywhere, All at Once” https://t.co/5GbGf7qhuw

urls.title: Daniels Domination: How the Farting Corpse Guys Became Oscar Contenders
urls.description: Directing duo Daniels (Kwan and Scheinert) have come a long way since Daniel Radcliffe's flatulent reanimated corpse prompted walkouts at the 2016 Sundance premiere of ‘Swiss Army Man.' THR’s Young Filmmakers of the Year talk obsessively planning for worst-case scenarios, their 13-year partnership, and what to expect after buzzy 'Everything Everywhere All at Once.'

urls.title: ‘I didn’t have a single audition for a year’: Goonies and Indiana Jones child star Ke Huy Quan on finding fame again
urls.description: Forced to quit Hollywood in his 20s through the lack of roles for Asian actors, he is back on screen in the hit Everything Everywhere All at Once. He talks about being a refugee, the wilderness years - and what tempted him to return

urls.title: At 93, Actor James Hong Reflects on Breaking Barriers and Seminal Roles

urls.title: Everything On A Bagel: A Conversation With Daniels : Short Wave
urls.description: Directing Duo Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, (collectively: Daniels) are known for their first feature film Swiss Army Man and DJ Snake's and Lil Jon's music video "Turn Down For What." This year, they've taken their directing to a whole different universe. Host Emily Kwong chats with the Daniels about their new film Everything Everywhere All At Once and how their indie film about laundry and taxes melds the arts with sciences. You can follow Emily on Twitter @EmilyKwong1234. Email Short Wave at ShortWave@NPR.org.

tweets.text:
All these epic bagel hair + hot dog finger #EEAllOween costumes compels me to share MY MOST FAVORITE @NPRShortWave interview ever 👀
